title: Missing trie node after removedb
body:
Hi everyone, after I use `geth -datadir=XXX removedb`, geth syncs normally, but the `Latest Block` is always 0.
After ~15 hours, when the `Latest header` and `Latest receipt` are the same height as the `Latest receipt` is the same. 
![system](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/assets/19996579/2998b4aa-c6d7-42b1-b7d8-ecc769cf90d9)
![blockchain](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/assets/19996579/33e48e87-508b-4154-aa49-384626eb69b7)


However, in the console `debug.dumpBlock(100)`, it will still show `Missing trie node`
![dump](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/assets/19996579/e078e6d2-d533-4eeb-903e-282db65e58ac)

The geth runs well, here is the latest 20 lines of log
![log](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/assets/19996579/8f224427-c225-4509-b125-fe1a6dbf9e03)

My geth starts with
```cmd
geth --mainnet \
     --syncmode full \
     --gcmode archive \
     --http \
     --http.addr ${rpcaddr} \
     --http.vhosts "*" \
     --http.api "eth,net,web3,debug,admin" \
     --http.port "8545" \
     --http.corsdomain "*" \
     --ws \
     --ws.addr ${rpcaddr} \
     --ws.origins '*' \
     --ws.api "eth,net,web3,debug,admin" \
     --authrpc.jwtsecret "XXX/jwt.hex" \
     --datadir ${datadir} \
     --metrics --metrics.influxdb \
     --metrics.influxdb.database "XXX" \
     --metrics.influxdb.endpoint "http://0.0.0.0:8086" \
     --metrics.influxdb.username "XXX" \
     --metrics.influxdb.password "XXX"
     --txlookuplimit 0 \
```

It doesn't sync full data as expected (e.g., something can be dumped), what should I do next?

Ps:
- I use the `removedb` because of `bad block`
- My geth version is 1.12.0-stable

Doing a `geth --removedb` deletes all your data. Yes, it is expected that head block goes back to zero. You wipe everything. 

> It doesn't sync full data as expected

That is correct. It does not, which is why you see this: 

> After ~15 hours, when the Latest header and Latest receipt are the same height as the Latest receipt

This indicates that snap-sync happened. Which is also the reason why it does not have the state for block `100`. 

So the only question is why it does not do a full sync. It would be interesting to see the first ~100 lines of output from when you started it the first time after the `geth --removedb` run.

> Doing a `geth --removedb` deletes all your data. Yes, it is expected that head block goes back to zero. You wipe everything.
> 
> > It doesn't sync full data as expected
> 
> That is correct. It does not, which is why you see this:
> 
> > After ~15 hours, when the Latest header and Latest receipt are the same height as the Latest receipt
> 
> This indicates that snap-sync happened. Which is also the reason why it does not have the state for block `100`.
> 
> So the only question is why it does not do a full sync. It would be interesting to see the first ~100 lines of output from when you started it the first time after the `geth --removedb` run.

Thanks for your reply. 
I restart my geth after use `geth --removedb`, so the ~100 lines of output are overwritten. 

But the first ~100 lines of the new output are

My questions are
- Should I re-run `geth --removedb` and look at the log?
- If it is now synp-sync, is there a way to change to full-sync on this basis instead of re-syncing?
